subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs
msgSnippet: Which JDK are you using?  You could also use the -Xrunhprof option (I think it is only available 1.2.x +).  Use the attached tail.exe to tail the file. See
messageBody:
Which JDK are you using? You could also use the -Xrunhprof option (I think
it is only available 1.2.x +). Use the attached tail.exe to tail the file.
See <http://java.sun.com/products/jdk/1.2/docs/guide/jvmpi/jvmpi.html#hprof>
for how to interpret -Xrunhprof, but basically you are looking for
ThreadStarts that don't have an associated ThreadEnd. This will tell you
where possible hangs are happening.

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@bjss.co.uk]
> Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 5:08 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs
>
>
> Run your tests with the text test runner. When it's hung do a
> Ctrl-Break (on unix you have to send a signal, not sure
> which one).
> This causes the JVM to do a thread dump. You can see a
> stack trace of
> each thread and hopefully find your deadlock.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Thach Nguyen [mailto:thach@adobe.com]
> Sent: 14 August 2001 18:20
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Recover from test hangs
>
>
> Hello,
>
> Could someone advice on how to perform recovery from test
> hangs. Thanks
> very much.
>
> Thach.
>
